elements.content: Azobenzenyl anion radical complex of magnesium [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(PhNNPh) (THF) (2) was obtained for the first time through the reaction of [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-­iPr2C6H3)2]­MgBr (1) with potassium graphite in the presence of azobenzene. Complex 2 is a useful electron-transfer reagent as shown by the reactivity with diphenyl disulfide, diphenyl diselenide, oxygen, sulfur, and Me3SiN3 yielding the magnesium thiolate [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(SPh)­(THF) (3), magnesium selenolate [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(SePh)­(THF) (4), peroxido complex {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(THF)}2(μ–η2-η2-O2) (5), persulfido complex {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(THF)}2(μ–η2-η2-S2) (6), and azido complex [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­MgN3 (7), respectively. Furthermore, treatment of 2 with Me3SiCHN2 results in a rearrangement product {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­[CNN­(SiMe3)]} 2 (8).

Complex 2 is a useful electron-transfer reagent as shown by the reactivity with diphenyl disulfide, diphenyl diselenide, oxygen, sulfur, and Me3SiN3 yielding the magnesium thiolate [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(SPh)(THF) (3), magnesium selenolate [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(SePh)(THF) (4), peroxido complex {[HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(THF)}2(μ-η2-η2-O2) (5), persulfido complex {[HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(THF)}2(μ-η2-η2-S2) (6), and azido complex [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]MgN3 (7), respectively. Furthermore, treatment of 2 with Me3SiCHN2 results in a rearrangement product {[HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg[CNN(SiMe3)]} 2  (8).

elements.content: Magnesium reducing reagents play important roles in organic and organometallic chemistry. Notable examples include the application of the Mg/MgX2 (X = Br or I) mixtures as one-electron reductants toward a variety of unsaturated substrates and the employment of the dimeric magnesium­(I) complexes as soluble, selective, and safe reducing agents in diverse reactions. Especially, the use of the dimeric magnesium­(I) reagents usually leads to outcomes that are not achievable with traditional reducing agents. Hence, exploration of more magnesium reducing reagents would be of great value to the organic chemists.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Magnesium reducing reagents play important roles in organic and organometallic chemistry. Notable examples include the application of the Mg/MgX2 (X = Br or I) mixtures as one-electron reductants toward a variety of unsaturated substrates and the employment of the dimeric magnesium(I) complexes as soluble, selective, and safe reducing agents in diverse reactions. Especially, the use of the dimeric magnesium(I) reagents usually leads to outcomes that are not achievable with traditional reducing agents. Hence, exploration of more magnesium reducing reagents would be of great value to the organic chemists.

elements.content: Redox noninnocent ligands can provide an alternative way to achieve the desired agents. Despite many magnesium complexes bearing diazabutadienes and bis­(arylimino)­acenaphthenes having been prepared, only a few of them exhibit significant reactivity. Thus, the development of novel magnesium complexes with redox noninnocent ligands is of great interest and importance. Additionally, the magnesium amides are also noteworthy compounds mainly due to their distinctive reactivity patterns and role in catalytic processes. The quest for new magnesium amides is still an ongoing work.

elements.content: As a redox noninnocent ligand, azobenzene can be populated by one or two electrons in a low-lying azo-centered vacant π* molecular orbital, resulting in a radical anion and hydrazido dianion, respectively (). In past years, many early transition-metal, lanthanide, and main-group metal complexes bearing reduced azobenzenyl ligand have been synthesized. However, the research efforts have been mainly focused on the NN bond activation of azobenzene. And the potential reducibility of the azobenzenyl radical complexes have been rarely explored to date. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, no examples of magnesium complexes with azobenzenyl radical ligand have been reported. Recently, we initiated a research program in this field. Herein, we report on some observations concerning the chemistry of an azobenzenyl radical complex of magnesium.

Herein, we report on some observations concerning the chemistry of an azobenzenyl radical complex of magnesium.

elements.content: Treatment of KC8 with a 1:1 mixture of azobenzene and [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­MgBr (1) in tetrahydrofuran (THF) solution gave the dark green azobenzenyl complex [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]-Mg­(PhNNPh) (THF) (2) in 86% yield (). The compound is air- and moisture-sensitive, but it can be stored without degradation in a dry nitrogen atmosphere. Complex 2 is soluble in and readily recrystallized from a toluene solution. It was fully characterized by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. However, the 1H NMR spectrum keeps silence in the range from −100 to 100 ppm. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum () of 2 in THF displays five major resonances, which is the splitting pattern expected for an unpaired electron coupled two 14N nuclei (I = 1). The 14N coupling constant is ∼7.6 G, which is larger than that of free (PhNNPh)·–. The isotropic g value is measured to be 2.004 (see Supporting Information Figure S1). The simulated EPR spectrum with these parameters agrees well with the experimental data. The UV/vis spectrum of dark green has an obvious absorption at 404 nm (ε = 5.35 × 102 M–1 cm–1) and a broad feature at 628 nm (ε = 1.73 × 102 M–1 cm–1) in THF (see Supporting Information Figure S3), which can be ascribed to the presence of the electron in the lowest antibonding orbital. Similarly, The azobenzenyl radical compound Na­(PhNNPh) shows absorptions at 433 and 628 nm, while the dianion shows only one bond at 379 nm. These results imply that 2 is a Mg­(II) complex, in which the azobenzenyl ligand serves as a radical monoanion.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(PhNNPh) (THF) (2)

Treatment of KC8 with a 1:1 mixture of azobenzene and [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]MgBr (1) in tetrahydrofuran (THF) solution gave the dark green azobenzenyl complex [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]-Mg(PhNNPh) (THF) (2) in 86% yield (). The compound is air- and moisture-sensitive, but it can be stored without degradation in a dry nitrogen atmosphere. Complex 2 is soluble in and readily recrystallized from a toluene solution. It was fully characterized by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. However, the 1H NMR spectrum keeps silence in the range from -100 to 100 ppm. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum () of 2 in THF displays five major resonances, which is the splitting pattern expected for an unpaired electron coupled two 14N nuclei (I = 1). The 14N coupling constant is ~7.6 G, which is larger than that of free (PhNNPh)⋅-. The isotropic g value is measured to be 2.004 (see Supporting Information Figure S1). The simulated EPR spectrum with these parameters agrees well with the experimental data. The UV/vis spectrum of dark green has an obvious absorption at 404 nm (ε = 5.35 × 102 M-1 cm-1) and a broad feature at 628 nm (ε = 1.73 × 102 M-1 cm-1) in THF (see Supporting Information Figure S3), which can be ascribed to the presence of the electron in the lowest antibonding orbital. Similarly, The azobenzenyl radical compound Na(PhNNPh) shows absorptions at 433 and 628 nm, while the dianion shows only one bond at 379 nm. These results imply that 2 is a Mg(II) complex, in which the azobenzenyl ligand serves as a radical monoanion.

elements.content: The molecular structure of 2 is shown in . To the best of our knowledge, 2 is the first magnesium complex with an azobenzenyl radical anion. As observed by other authors, the acceptance of an electron into neutral azobenzene results in lengthening of the N(1)–N(2) bond and in twisting of the azobenzenyl ligand. The Ph–N–N–Ph dihedral angle is 42.41°, which is close to that found in [η5-2,5-(Me3C)2-3,4-Me2C4P]2Tm­(PhNNPh) (41°) and [η5-2,5-(Me3Si)2-3,4-Me2C4P]2Sm­(PhNNPh) (39°). The N(1)–N(2) distance (1.3573(16) Å) is intermediate between the 1.25 Å NN double bond distance typical of azobenzene and the 1.45 Å sp3–sp3 N–N single bond distance typical of hydrazine and thus indicates reduction of the ligand. A similar value was observed in the known complexes [η5-2,5-(Me3C)2-3,4-Me2C4P]2Tm­(PhNNPh) (1.35 Å), [η5-2,5-(Me3Si)2-3,4-Me2C4P]2Sm­(PhNNPh) (1.35 Å), [(iPr3Si)2N)]2Sm­(PhNNPh) (1.353(4) Å), and in (C5Me5)2Sm­(PhNNPh) (THF) (1.32 and 1.39 Å), in which the azobenzenyl ligands are unambiguously described as radical monoanion.

elements.content: Azobenzene is a rather unusual redox noninnocent ligand, and most contributions in this area are dominated by diimine systems, such as 2,2′-bipyridine and diazabutadienes. The cyclic voltammetry investigation (see Supporting Information Figure S4) confirms that azobenzene appears to undergo two one-electron reductions. The first reduction wave is found at ca. −1.20 V, which indicates that azobenzene is much easier to reduce than 2,2′-bipyridine (−2.0 V; see Supporting Information Figure S5) or diazabutadienes. In addition, azobenzene is more readily reduced than Mg2+ (Mg2+/Mg+ couple: −2.05 V vs normal hydrogen electrode). These results imply that azobenzenyl magnesium complexes may posscess distinctive redox properties. Additionally, azobenzenyl magnesium chemistry is virtually unexplored to date.
elements.clean_text:
Reactivity of [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(PhNNPh)(THF) (2)

Azobenzene is a rather unusual redox noninnocent ligand, and most contributions in this area are dominated by diimine systems, such as 2,2'-bipyridine and diazabutadienes. The cyclic voltammetry investigation (see Supporting Information Figure S4) confirms that azobenzene appears to undergo two one-electron reductions. The first reduction wave is found at ca. -1.20 V, which indicates that azobenzene is much easier to reduce than 2,2'-bipyridine (-2.0 V; see Supporting Information Figure S5) or diazabutadienes. In addition, azobenzene is more readily reduced than Mg2+ (Mg2+/Mg+ couple: -2.05 V vs normal hydrogen electrode). These results imply that azobenzenyl magnesium complexes may posscess distinctive redox properties. Additionally, azobenzenyl magnesium chemistry is virtually unexplored to date.

elements.content: However, Mg/MgX2 (X = Br or I) mixtures can act as one-electron reductants in many organic reactions. For example, Mg/MgI2 mixture can reduce a ketone to yield a C–C bond coupling product, in which the subvalent magnesium iodide MgI· was proposed as reductant. Given that the complex 2 is also a magnesium radical compound, we deduced that it might be useful for reductive synthetic chemistry and may expand the scope of magnesium reducing agents. Therefore, we investigated the reactivity of complex 2 with a series of oxidizing reagents.
elements.clean_text: However, Mg/MgX2 (X = Br or I) mixtures can act as one-electron reductants in many organic reactions. For example, Mg/MgI2 mixture can reduce a ketone to yield a C-C bond coupling product, in which the subvalent magnesium iodide MgI⋅ was proposed as reductant. Given that the complex 2 is also a magnesium radical compound, we deduced that it might be useful for reductive synthetic chemistry and may expand the scope of magnesium reducing agents. Therefore, we investigated the reactivity of complex 2 with a series of oxidizing reagents.

elements.content: Magnesium chalcogenolates are valuable species, due to their roles in wide band-gap semiconductors and synthetic chemistry. Therefore, the synthesis of these compounds is of great importance. Herein, we found that complex 2 can break S–S and Se–Se bonds to give magnesium thiolates and selenolates. For example, reaction of 2 with 0.5 equiv of PhSSPh or PhSeSePh resulted in a S–S or Se–Se bond cleavage to produce [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(EPh)­(THF) (E = S (3), Se (4)) in 84% and 81% yield, respectively ().

For example, reaction of 2 with 0.5 equiv of PhSSPh or PhSeSePh resulted in a S-S or Se-Se bond cleavage to produce [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(EPh)(THF) (E = S (3), Se (4)) in 84% and 81% yield, respectively ().

elements.content: Likewise, activation of small molecules by complex 2 was also observed. For instance, exposure of reaction solutions to the oxygen atmosphere was found to result in decolorisation of the distinctive (dark green) color, which was attributed to the formation of the free azobenzene. In that case, reaction of complex 2 with O2 generated the well-defined dimeric magnesium peroxide species {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(THF)}2(μ–η2-η2-O2) (5) (). In addition, O2 activation is well-documented for the dimeric magnesium­(I) compound.

In addition, O2 activation is well-documented for the dimeric magnesium(I) compound.

elements.content: The reduction chemistry of the azobenzenyl radical complex with elemental sulfur was also examined. Like divalent ytterbium complex LYbN­(SiMe3)2 (L = Me4C5–SiMe2–­NC4H4) and bimetallic yttrium complex {[(Me3Si)2N2]­Y­(THF)}2(N2), the treatment of complex 2 with S8 gave the first persulfido magnesium complex {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(THF)}2(μ–η2-η2-S2) (6), along with the byproduct neutral azobenzene ().

Like divalent ytterbium complex LYbN(SiMe3)2 (L = Me4C5-SiMe2-NC4H4) and bimetallic yttrium complex {[(Me3Si)2N2]Y(THF)}2(N2), the treatment of complex 2 with S8 gave the first persulfido magnesium complex {[HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(THF)}2(μ-η2-η2-S2) (6), along with the byproduct neutral azobenzene ().

elements.content: In contrast to the dimeric magnesium­(I) compound, the reaction of 2 with Me3SiN3 does not yield a hexazenediide. Instead, the azido complex [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­MgN3 (7) was isolated along with the byproducts, free azobenzene, and Me3SiSiMe3 (). This work represents the first example of the azido magnesium complex obtained by the direct reductive N–Si bond cleavage of Me3SiN3 with a magnesium electron transfer agent, though the azido compound [Mg­(TPP)­(N3)] was synthesized by reaction of [Mg­(TPP)] (TPP = tetraphenylporphyrinato) with KN3. These reactions illustrate that the radical monoanion azobenzenyl magnesium complex can serve as a one-electron reductant.

These reactions illustrate that the radical monoanion azobenzenyl magnesium complex can serve as a one-electron reductant.

elements.content: Encouraged by the initial screening, the reactivity of 2 with organic diazoalkane Me3SiCHN2 was investigated. The reaction of 2 with diazoalkane compound does not form the diazo complex, while a silyl group, as well as moiety, shifts from the diazo carbon atom to the end-on nitrogen atom of the diazogermylene yielded the isonitril complex {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6- iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­[CNN­(SiMe3)]} 2 (8) along with azobenzene and other unidentified compounds. A comparable migration of a silyl group of azides is found in organolanthanides and germanium complex. The compound 8 is the first isonitril magnesium synthon with Me3SiCHN2.

elements.clean_text:
Structure Characterizations

The complexes 3, 4, and 6-8 are stable in a dry nitrogen atmosphere, while they are moisture-sensitive. They were characterized by various spectroscopic techniques and elemental analyses. In addition, the solid-state structures of these complexes were further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: The ORTEP diagrams of [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(SPh)­(THF) (3) and [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(SePh)­(THF) (4) are shown in and . The Mg atoms in 3 and 4 show a severely distorted tetrahedral geometry, with angles ranging from 94.40(8) to 128.99(7)° and from 94.35(8) to 127.13(6)°, respectively. The 2.3839(9) Å Mg–S and 2.4988(8) Å Mg–Se distances in 3 and 4, respectively are close to those found in Mg­(SMes)2(Et2O)2 (Mes = 2,4,6-tBu3C6H2) (2.382(2) and 2.392(2) Å), Mg­(THF)2(N­(SiMe3)2)­(SMes) (2.431(2) Å), and Mg­(SeMes)2(THF)2 (2.536(3) and 2.539(3) Å). The angle of C(1)–S(1)–Mg(1) (106.63(9)°) is smaller than that of Mg­(SMes)2(Et2O)2 (116.6(1) and 117.1(1)°), whereas the angle of C(1)–Se(1)–Mg(1) (104.16(8)°) is similar to that of Mg­(SeMes)2(THF)2 (100.7(2) and 101.8(2)°).

elements.content: The molecular structure of [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­MgN3 (7) is shown in . The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 7 establishes a one-dimensional infinite chain {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­MgN3}∞ in the crystal lattice, which is formed by intermolecular Mg···N3 interactions. The Mg atom in each molecular structure shows a severely distorted tetrahedral geometry, with angles ranging from 97.15(7) to 124.34(9)°. The Mg–N­(nitride) distances (1.972(2) and 2.054(2) Å) are consistent with those of [Mg­(TPP)­(N3)]− (1.997(2) Å). The N(1)–N(2) (1.153(3) Å) and N(2)–N(3) (1.172(3) Å) distances are close to those of [Mg­(TPP)­(N3)]− (1.193(3) and 1.198(3) Å)and [Cd­(TPP)­(N3)]− (1.163(2) and 1.176(2) Å), which suggests that the N­(I) atom has sp2 hybridization. The angle of Mg–N(1)–N(2) (142.48(18)°) is smaller than that of [Mg­(TPP)­(N3)]−(156.1­(2)°).

elements.content: depicts the molecular structure of {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­[CNN­(SiMe3)]}2 (8), which reveals a centro-symmetric dimer. The Mg atom shows a severely distorted tetrahedral geometry with angles ranging from 95.11 (5) to 117.70(5)°. The N(1)–Si(1) bond length of 1.7567(12) Å compares well to the N–Si distances (1.725(2)–1.732(2) Å) and not to typical C–Si bond lengths (1.81–1.84 Å). A resonance form in which N(1) has neutral donor character and C(1) is anionic may also be involved, that is, formally Mg–N­(SiMe3)NC. For example, the 1.3302(16) Å N(1)–N(2) bond length in 8 is shorter than expected for a single bond (1.41–1.45 Å), and the Mg(1)–N(1) (2.0853(12) Å) bond length is long compared to the Mg–N bond length in [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(NiPr2) (1.938(2) Å) and [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­[N­(SiMe3)2] (1.961(2) Å). However, the N(2)–C(1) bond length (1.1602(18) Å) is comparable to the corresponding average distances in bridged cyanide magnesium, 1.160, 1.165, and 1.174 Å in {[HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­[μ-CN)]}3, and the Mg(1)–C(1) bond length of 2.1705(14) Å compares to Mg–C≡N distance of 2.12(2) Å in {Mg­[CH­(SiMe3)2]­(μ-Br)­(CN t Bu)}2, which is shorter than that of 2.307(10) and 2.306(9) Å in Mg­[CH­(SiMe3)2]­(CNC6H3Me2-2,6)2.

elements.content: In summary, the first azobenzenyl monoanion radical complex of magnesiun [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(PhNNPh) (THF) (2) has been prepared and structurally characterized. The complex 2 can react with a wide range of substrates such as diphenyl disulfide, diphenyl diselenide, oxygen, elemental sulfur, Me3SiN3, and Me3SiCHN2. Moreover, this reactivity allowed the isolation of several novel magnesium compounds, such as persulfido complex 6, azido compound 7, and isonitril complex 8, which otherwise are difficult to prepare. In addition, as one-electron reductant, the compound 2 and the magnesium­(I) complexes show similar reaction behavior toward O2. However, the different reactivity pattern between them was also observed. For example, reaction of 2 with azide produces an azido complex, while the dimeric magnesium­(I) compound undergoes a reductive N–N coupling reaction. Taken as a whole, these initial results demonstrate how redox noninnocent ligands can be employed as reducing agents in synthetic transformations. The further catalytic chemistry of the azobenzenyl magnesiun complex is currently being explored.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, the first azobenzenyl monoanion radical complex of magnesiun [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(PhNNPh) (THF) (2) has been prepared and structurally characterized. The complex 2 can react with a wide range of substrates such as diphenyl disulfide, diphenyl diselenide, oxygen, elemental sulfur, Me3SiN3, and Me3SiCHN2. Moreover, this reactivity allowed the isolation of several novel magnesium compounds, such as persulfido complex 6, azido compound 7, and isonitril complex 8, which otherwise are difficult to prepare. In addition, as one-electron reductant, the compound 2 and the magnesium(I) complexes show similar reaction behavior toward O2. However, the different reactivity pattern between them was also observed. For example, reaction of 2 with azide produces an azido complex, while the dimeric magnesium(I) compound undergoes a reductive N-N coupling reaction. Taken as a whole, these initial results demonstrate how redox noninnocent ligands can be employed as reducing agents in synthetic transformations. The further catalytic chemistry of the azobenzenyl magnesiun complex is currently being explored.

elements.content: All reactions and manipulations were performed under an atmosphere of dry dinitrogen with rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. PhCHO was distilled under nitrogen prior to use. S8 and azobenzene were purified by sublimation. [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­MgBr and KC8 were prepared according to literature methods. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and Energy Chemical Co. and were used as received unless otherwise noted. Caution! Diphenyl diselenide is a toxic compound and should be handled carefully. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on an Avatar 360 Fourier transform spectrometer. Ultraviolet spectrum was performed on a Unico UV-4802H spectro-photometer. 1H and 13C­{1H} NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 600 spectrometer at 600 and 150 MHz, respectively. All chemical shifts were reported in δ units with reference to the residual protons of the deuterated solvents, which were internal standards, for proton and carbon chemical shifts. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopic measurements were performed on Bruker E500 console. The experimental spectrum was simulated with the computer simulation software packages XSophe–Sophe–XeprView. Melting points were measured on an X-6 melting point apparatus and were uncorrected. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL elemental analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All reactions and manipulations were performed under an atmosphere of dry dinitrogen with rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. PhCHO was distilled under nitrogen prior to use. S8 and azobenzene were purified by sublimation. [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]MgBr and KC8  were prepared according to literature methods. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and Energy Chemical Co. and were used as received unless otherwise noted.  Caution! Diphenyl diselenide is a toxic compound and should be handled carefully. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on an Avatar 360 Fourier transform spectrometer. Ultraviolet spectrum was performed on a Unico UV-4802H spectro-photometer. 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 600 spectrometer at 600 and 150 MHz, respectively. All chemical shifts were reported in δ units with reference to the residual protons of the deuterated solvents, which were internal standards, for proton and carbon chemical shifts. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopic measurements were performed on Bruker E500 console. The experimental spectrum was simulated with the computer simulation software packages XSophe-Sophe-XeprView. Melting points were measured on an X-6 melting point apparatus and were uncorrected. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL elemental analyzer.

elements.content: KC8 (0.5 g, 3.7 mmol) was added to a THF (20 mL) solution of [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­MgBr (1; 2.00 g, 3.8 mmol) and azobenzene (0.69 g, 3.8 mmol) with stirring at room temperature. After this solution was stirred at 40 °C for 2 d, the solvent was removed. The residue was extracted with toluene (10 mL × 3) and filtered. Concentration to ∼10 mL and storage at room temperature gave 2 as dark green crystals, which were isolated by filtration. Yield: 2.27 g (86%). mp 218–220 °C (dec). IR (KBr): ν = 2958 (m), 2923 (m), 2865 (m), 1619 (m), 1543 (m), 1514 (m), 1458 (m), 1432 (m), 1405 (s), 1362 (m), 1312 (m), 1258 (m), 1097 (m), 1020 (s), 927 (m), 881 (m), 791 (s) cm–1. Anal. Preparation of [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(PhNNPh) (THF) (2)

KC8 (0.5 g, 3.7 mmol) was added to a THF (20 mL) solution of [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]MgBr (1; 2.00 g, 3.8 mmol) and azobenzene (0.69 g, 3.8 mmol) with stirring at room temperature. After this solution was stirred at 40 °C for 2 d, the solvent was removed. The residue was extracted with toluene (10 mL × 3) and filtered. Concentration to ~10 mL and storage at room temperature gave 2 as dark green crystals, which were isolated by filtration. Yield: 2.27 g (86%). mp 218-220 °C (dec). IR (KBr): ν = 2958 (m), 2923 (m), 2865 (m), 1619 (m), 1543 (m), 1514 (m), 1458 (m), 1432 (m), 1405 (s), 1362 (m), 1312 (m), 1258 (m), 1097 (m), 1020 (s), 927 (m), 881 (m), 791 (s) cm-1. Anal. elements.content: A THF (5 mL) solution of PhSSPh (0.11 g, 0.5 mmol) was added to a THF (10 mL) solution of [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(PhNNPh)­(THF) (2; 0.7 g, 1 mmol) with stirring at room temperature. During the course of the reaction, the color of the solution changed from dark green to yellow. After the solution was stirred at room temperature for 2 h, the solution was filtered. elements.content: PhSSPh (2.2 mg; 0.01 mmol) was added to a J. Young NMR tube charged with [HC­(C­(Me)­N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]­Mg­(PhNNPh)­(THF) (2; 14 mg, 0.02 mmol) and THF (0.5 mL). The color of the solution immediately changed from dark green to yellow. The solvent was slowly removed, and the residue was dissolved in C6D5N (0.5 mL). Resonances due to 3 along with those of azobenzene (1H NMR (C6D5N): δ 8.05 (m, 2H, phenyl), 7.51 (m, 2H, phenyl), 7.45 (m, 1H, phenyl)) and THF (1H NMR (C6D5N): δ 3.65 (m), 1,62 (m)) were observed by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

Method B. Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Scale

PhSSPh (2.2 mg; 0.01 mmol) was added to a J. Young NMR tube charged with [HC(C(Me)N-2,6-iPr2C6H3)2]Mg(PhNNPh)(THF) (2; 14 mg, 0.02 mmol) and THF (0.5 mL). The color of the solution immediately changed from dark green to yellow. The solvent was slowly removed, and the residue was dissolved in C6D5N (0.5 mL). elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on an Agilent SuperNova EosS2 diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 84 Å). The crystals were kept at 100(10) K during data collection. The structures were solved by the Superflip structure solution program in Olex2 and refined using full-matrix least squares based on F 2 with program SHELXL-97 and the SHELXL-2014 within Olex2. Crystal data and experimental data for 2–4 and 6–9 are summarized in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on an Agilent SuperNova EosS2 diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). The crystals were kept at 100(10) K during data collection. The structures were solved by the Superflip structure solution program in Olex2 and refined using full-matrix least squares based on F 2 with program SHELXL-97 and the SHELXL-2014 within Olex2. Crystal data and experimental data for 2-4 and 6-9 are summarized in Table S1.
